channel.title: NYT > Health
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Giants at the Heart of the Opioid Crisis
item.media:description: The headquarters of McKesson Corporation, the drug distributing giant, in San Francisco.
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.description: Civil suits filed by three states accuse pharmaceutical distributors of flooding the country with opioids while devising systems to evade regulators.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Hospitals Stand to Lose Billions Under ‘Medicare for All’
item.media:description: Proponents held up signs as Senator Bernie Sanders introduced the Medicare for All bill in Washington this month.
item.description: Private insurance pays hospitals much more than the federal government does for patient care. If Medicare for all means Medicare rates, expect an industry backlash.
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON

item.title: A Vicious, Untreatable Killer Leaves China Guessing
item.media:description: The Wangaofa Animal Husbandry Development Company had to cull thousands of pigs this year after an outbreak of African swine fever. The facility now sits empty, its hallways splattered white with disinfecting lime.
item.description: African swine fever, which harms pigs but not humans, has swept across the country, the world’s largest pork producer. And those are only the cases the government knows about.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG and AILIN TANG

item.title: Personal Health: Should You Be Eating Eggs?
item.description: Do eggs raise your cholesterol? The advice keeps changing.
item.dc:creator: JANE E. BRODY

item.title: Wary of Chinese Espionage, Houston Cancer Center Chose to Fire 3 Scientists
item.media:description: The MD Anderson Cancer Center said it decided to fire three scientists who, among other allegations, failed to disclose international collaborators. Two of them resigned.
item.media:credit: Scott Dalton for The New York Times
item.description: The director of the National Institutes of Health said that 55 similar investigations into possible foreign exploitation of American research are happening nationwide.
item.dc:creator: MIHIR ZAVERI
item.category: University of Texas M D Anderson Cancer Center

item.title: Well : Why Does Exercise Guard Against Cancer? Inflammation May Play a Role
item.description: How exercise guards against colon cancer and other types of cancer remains a mystery.
item.dc:creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

item.title: This Genetic Mutation Makes People Feel Full — All the Time
item.media:description: Mutations in the MC4R gene usually lead to obesity by preventing a sense of fullness. But one such mutation leaves people uninterested in eating, scientists report.
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.description: Two new studies confirm that weight control is often the result of genetics, not willpower.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: In India, a Renewed Fight Against Leprosy
item.media:description: The hands of Bodhe Annasuya, 45, who acquired leprosy when she was 12 years old. She lives in Balaji Nagar, a leprosy colony, with her husband and adopted son, in Hyderabad, India.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.description: Health workers thought they had vanquished the disease in 2005. But it lived on, cloaked in stigma and medical mystery.
item.dc:creator: APOORVA MANDAVILLI
item.category: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

item.title: Senator McConnell, a Tobacco Ally, Supports Raising Age to Buy Cigarettes
item.media:description: Leading lawmakers are gathering support for legislation at the federal and state levels to curtail sales of tobacco and vaping products to young adults.
item.description: Seeking re-election to a seventh term, the senator cited the rise in teenage vaping as a reason to curtail sales of tobacco and other products.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN

item.title: Skipping Breakfast May Increase Stroke and Heart Risks
item.description: Eating breakfast could be a simple way to promote cardiovascular health, one researcher says.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR
item.category: Journal of the American College of Cardiology

item.title: At War: The Military Wants Better Tests for PTSD. Speech Analysis Could Be the Answer.
item.media:description: Dr. Charles Marmar, one of the authors of the study, looking at veterans’ brain scans in 2013.
item.description: Using computerized voice analysis, a new study found 18 features of speech that identify markers of PTSD in veterans.
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The New Health Care: What Can the U.S. Health System Learn From Singapore?
item.media:description: Tourists pass the glass dome of the Gardens by the Bay in Singapore.
item.description: Americans argue over insurance while Singaporeans keep perfecting the delivery of care.
item.dc:creator: AARON E. CARROLL

item.title: The Checkup: The Search for a Biomarker for Early Autism Diagnosis
item.description: Children with autism spectrum disorder took significantly longer to look away from a video when their names were called, a new study found.
item.dc:creator: PERRI KLASS, M.D.

item.title: Travel Tips: How to Protect Yourself From Air Pollution While Traveling
item.description: Poor air quality is a growing problem for travelers headed abroad. Here’s how to read up before you go, and protect yourself once you’re there.
item.dc:creator: HAHNA YOON

item.title: Before Fisher-Price’s Rock ’n Play Recall, Safety Fears and Dubious Marketing
item.media:description: Fisher-Price issued a recall for its Rock ’n Play sleeper this month after it was linked to multiple infant deaths.
item.media:credit: Consumer Product Safety Commission, via Associated Press
item.description: The company knew for years about potential risks linked to its popular sleeper and about pediatricians’ objections to the way the product was being pitched to parents.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY HSU

item.title: Strategies: ‘Medicare for All’ Is Hammering Health Care Stocks. For Now.
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders at a Fox News Town Hall on April 15. Mr. Sanders has been a prominent supporter of a “Medicare for All” health insurance program.
item.description: The popularity of proposals for a government-run, single-payer system among Democratic presidential candidates has hurt health care stocks, despite their strong earnings.
item.dc:creator: JEFF SOMMER

item.title: Ask Well: How Low Should Blood Pressure Go?
item.description: Symptoms, rather than numbers, may best define when blood pressure is too low.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD KLASCO, M.D.

item.title: Commuting While Pregnant: A Long Ride Could Be a Risky One
item.description: Traveling 50 or more miles to and from work may negatively affect unborn babies, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: Here’s Soylent’s New Product. It’s Food.
item.media:description: The three varietals of Soylent Squared.
item.description: The Silicon Valley food-drink of choice is now a ‘complete nutrition platform.’ The beverage plot thickens.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH and JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: Living With Cancer: The Lifesaving Power in Stem Cells
item.media:description: Dr. Hal Broxmeyer at Indiana University with the containers used to ship cryopreserved cord blood for Matthew Farrow, the first cord blood transplant patient in 1988, and other early recipients of sibling cord blood transplants.
item.description: Liars and thieves should not be allowed to detract from legitimate scientific research that has made umbilical cord blood mystic in its regenerative powers.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN GUBAR

item.title: Prostate Drugs May Raise Diabetes Risk
item.description: Proscar and Avodart, prescribed for an enlarged prostate, were tied to an increased risk of Type 2 diabetes.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: The Right Way to Use a Public Bathroom (to Avoid Getting Sick)
item.description: The odds of becoming ill from using a public bathroom are slim. But there are a few things you can do to minimize your risk even more. Here’s what to keep in mind.
item.dc:creator: MELINDA WENNER MOYER

item.title: Dr. Richard Green, 82, Dies; Challenged Psychiatry’s View of Homosexuality
item.media:description: Dr. Richard Green in an undated photo. In 1972, he defied the advice of colleagues and wrote a paper in The International Journal of Psychiatry questioning “the premise that homosexuality is a disease or a homosexual is inferior.”
item.description: At a time when being gay was classified as a mental disorder, Dr. Green defied the advice of his colleagues and took a professional risk by arguing otherwise.
item.dc:creator: BENEDICT CAREY

item.title: Deadly germs, lost cures: How a Chicago Woman Fell Victim to Candida Auris, a Drug-Resistant Fungus
item.media:description: Stephanie Spoor, center, with her husband, Gregory, left, during a bedside wedding ceremony of her son, Zack, to his new wife, Carley (right), at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. Ms. Spoor died just a few days later.
item.description: The mysterious infection has appeared at hospitals around the world, but few institutions or families have discussed their experience.
item.dc:creator: MATT RICHTEL

item.title: Trilobites: Look What the Cat Dragged In: Parasites
item.media:description: Cats can contract parasites from insects, prey, soil or other animals and can spread them to humans, pets or wildlife.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers found that house cats that roam outdoors were more likely to pick up diseases than indoor cats.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: ‘Partly Alive’: Scientists Revive Cells in Brains From Dead Pigs
item.media:description: Neurons (green), astrocytes (red), and cell nuclei (blue) in the brains of pigs. On left, brain tissue left untreated for 10 hours after death; right, brain tissue subjected to the experiment.
item.media:credit: Stefano G. Daniele and Zvonimir Vrselja, Yale School of Medicine
item.description: In a study that upends assumptions about brain death, researchers brought some cells back to life — or something like it.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Stress Tied to Heart Disease, Especially in People Under 50
item.description: Someone with a stress disorder was 37 percent more likely to develop cardiovascular disease than those in the general population.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Generation Grandparent: Anna Quindlen’s ‘Life in the 60s’
item.media:credit: Sara Naomi Lewkowicz for The New York Times
item.description: A Bubbe and a Nana share the joys of grandparenting: “This is the closest we get to immortality, right?”
item.dc:creator: PAULA SPAN

item.title: Phys Ed: 10 Years After an Exercise Study, Benefits Persist
item.description: The benefits of exercise may last longer than many of us might expect.
item.dc:creator: GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

item.title: Stanford Clears Professor of Helping With Gene-Edited Babies Experiment
item.media:description: Stephen Quake, a professor of biotechnology at Stanford University.
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.description: Stephen Quake and two colleagues were found to have followed proper scientific protocol in their interactions with the Chinese researcher who did the work.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK

item.title: F.D.A. Halts U.S. Sales of Pelvic Mesh, Citing Safety Concerns for Women
item.description: Boston Scientific and Coloplast were the last two companies selling the medical devices, which have resulted in nearly $8 billion in settlements.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Employee Wellness Programs Yield Little Benefit, Study Shows
item.media:description: Researchers followed thousands of BJ’s Wholesale Club employees for a year to monitor the effects of wellness programs. Although many who enrolled in the programs reported exercising more often and eating more healthfully, the study did not find significant medical care savings.
item.description: A rigorous new study calls into question whether workplace wellness programs can quickly save employers money on health care bills.
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn

item.title: Don’t Count on 23andMe to Detect Most Breast Cancer Risks, Study Warns
item.media:description: More than 10 million people have signed up for 23andMe. Many are initially drawn in by ancestry data, but later opt in for health risk tests.
item.description: The DNA testing company, which has 10 million customers, misses nearly 90 percent of people with risky BRCA mutations. It says the criticism is overblown.
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY

item.title: Nonfiction: A Psychotherapist Analyzes Her Patients’ Stories — and Her Own
item.media:description: The psychotherapist Lori Gottlieb draws on her patients’ stories, and her own, in her new memoir.
item.media:credit: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times
item.description: Lori Gottlieb’s “Maybe You Should Talk to Someone: A Therapist, Her Therapist, and Our Lives Revealed” is a treasure trove of stories and hard-earned advice.
item.dc:creator: ALEX KUCZYNSKI
item.category: Maybe You Should Talk to Someone: A Therapist, HER Therapist, and Our Lives Revealed (Book)

item.title: Parents Mourning Stillbirth Follow Familiar Patterns on YouTube
item.media:description: “I think without the video it may have been more difficult for people to comprehend that she was here,” Kaytee Fisher said of her daughter, Elliott Rose.
item.description: Over the course of about 15 years, a researcher says, YouTube has become a kind of virtual cemetery for parents experiencing stillbirth.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE RO
